facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1915 of 1970 filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL Appeal No. 1915 of 1970  Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment

facts.text: Appeal from Gujarat High Court Judgment/Order dated 2nd/3rd March 1970 in Revision Appln. No. 371 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment Order dated the 2nd/3rd March, 1970 of the Gujarat High Court in Revision Appln. No. 371 of 1966.

facts.text: Suit premises is a building known as Abdul Ratman Manzil belonging to Haji Mohamad Haji Dada Wakf Trust.

anchor.surface_text: The suit premises companysisted of a building known as Abdul Rat man Manzil and it belonged to one Haji Mohamad, Haji Dada Wakf  Trust .

facts.text: Building leased to Osman Jamal and Company under rent note dated January 15, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The building was leased to Osman Jamal and Company under a rent numbere dated January 15, 1947.

facts.text: In or about 1951, Osman Jamal and Company wound up and appellants took premises on monthly rent of Rs. 320/-

anchor.surface_text: In or about the year 1951, the firm of Osman Jamal and Company was wound up and the appellants took the premises on rent on a monthly rent of Rs. 320/-

facts.text: Landlord terminated tenancy by notice dated February 12, 1964 on grounds of rent default and sub-letting.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, the landlord, purported to terminate this tenancy by a. numberice dated February 12, 1964 on the ground that the appellants  tenants  had defaulted in the payment of rent and had sub- let the premises.

facts.text: At trial, plea of rent default given up by respondent; sole issue was whether appellants sub-let premises.

anchor.surface_text: At the trial of the suit, the plea that the appellants companymitted default in payment of rent was given up and, therefore, the sole issue before the Court was whether the appellants had sub-let the premises.

facts.text: Appellants contended lease contract allowed sub-letting.

anchor.surface_text: The companytention of the appellants was that under the companytract of lease, they had the right to sub-let the promises and, there-fore,

facts.text: Trial court (District Judge Jamnagar) held tenancy contract had no prohibition on sub-letting, dismissed suit.

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt held that the companytract of tenancy companytained numberprohibition against the tenant sub-letting the premises and so, the respondent was number entitled to recover possession of the premises

facts.text: District Judge allowed respondent's appeal, decreed suit for possession under Saurashtra Act s.13(1)(e).

anchor.surface_text: The respondent. filed an appeal against this decree before the District Judge. He held that s. 15 of the Saurashtra Rent Control Act, 1951

facts.text: Saurashtra Rent Control Act, 1951 repealed on December 31, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: He further held that the repeal of the Saurashtra Act by the Bombay Rents, Hotel and Lodging House Rates  Control  Act, 1947  hereinafter referred to as The Bombay Act  on December 31, 1963,

facts.text: Bombay Rents Act applied to area on January 1, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: As already stated, the Saurashtra Act was repealed on December 31, 1963 the Bombay Act was made applicable to the area in question on January 1, 1964.

facts.text: Appellants sub-let premises while Saurashtra Act was in force.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants sub-let the premises while the Saurashtra Act was in force in the area.

facts.text: Notice to terminate issued after repeal of Saurashtra Act on February 12, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: The numberice to terminate the tenancy was issued by the landlord on February 12, 1964 i.e., after the Saurashtra Act was repealed

facts.text: Suit filed after Bombay Act came into force.

anchor.surface_text: and the suit was filed for recovery of possession of the premises after the Bombay Act came into force.

facts.text: Gujarat High Court Division Bench confirmed decree for ejectment.

anchor.surface_text: The Division Bench, by its judgment, held that the suit to recover possession of the premises was companypetent under s. 13 1  e  of the Saurashtra Act numberwithstanding the repeal of that Act

facts.text: Supreme Court held landlord had accrued right to recover possession under Saurashtra Act s.13(1)(e) upon sub-letting, surviving repeal.

anchor.surface_text: It would follow that a right accrued to the landlord to recover possession under s. 13 1  of the Saurashtra Act when the tenant sub-let the premises during the currency of that Act

facts.text: No notice required under Saurashtra Act or Transfer of Property Act to terminate tenancy for sub-letting.

anchor.surface_text: The Saurashtra Act numberhere insists that the landlord should issue a numberice and terminate the tenancy before instituting a suit for recovery of possession under s. 13 1  e

facts.text: Tenancy contract did not prohibit sub-letting.

anchor.surface_text: the companytract of tenancy companytained numberprohibition against the tenant sub-letting the premises

facts.text: Appellants sub-let the premises.

anchor.surface_text: and had sub- let the premises.

issues.text: whether the High Court was right in dismissing a revision petition filed by the appellants and thereby upholding the judgment of the learned District Judge, Jamnagar, decreeing the suit filed by respondent No. 1 for possession of the suit premises

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal, by special leave, the question for consideration is whether the High Court was right in dismissing a revision petition filed by the appellants and thereby upholding the judgment of the learned District Judge, Jamnagar, decreeing the suit filed by respondent No. 1 for possession of the suit premises.

issues.text: Whether the landlord is entitled to maintain a suit for recovery of possession from the tenant on the ground of sub-letting under section 13(1)(e) of the Bombay Rent Act No. 57 of 1947, as applied to Gujarat State on 31 December 1963, where the sub-letting was made during the pendency of the Saurashtra Rent Control Act and neither the notice to terminate the contract was given nor the suit was filed before the date on which the Saurashtra Rent Control Act was repealed

anchor.surface_text: The question before the Division Bench was Whether the landlord is entitled to maintain a suit for recovery of possession from the tenant. On the ground of sub-letting under section 13 1  e  of the Bombay Rent Act  No. 57 of 1947 , as applied to Gujarat State on 31 December 1963 , where the sub-letting was made during the pendency of the Saurashtra Rent Control Act and neither the notice to terminate the contract was given nor the suit was filed before the date on which the Saurashtra Rent Control Act was repealed ?

issues.text: Whether section 15 of the Saurashtra Rent Control Act, 1951 superseded the contract of tenancy prohibiting sub-letting notwithstanding any contract to the contrary

anchor.surface_text: He held that s. 15 of the Saurashtra Rent Control Act, 1951 hereinafter referred to as the Saurashtra Act which prohibited a tenant from Sub-letting the premises superseded the contract of tenancy between the parties as that section was not subject to any contract to the contrary and, therefore, the landlord obtained the right to recover possession of the premises by virtue of s. 13 1  e  of the Saurashtra Act.

issues.text: Whether notice terminating the tenancy was required before instituting a suit for recovery of possession under s.13(1)(e) of the Saurashtra Act on the ground of sub-letting

anchor.surface_text: The Saurashtra Act nowhere insists that the landlord should issue a notice and terminate the tenancy before instituting a suit for recovery of possession under s. 13 1  e on the ground that the tenant had sub-lot the premises.

anchor.surface_text: It would follow that a right accrued to the landlord to recover possession under s. 13 1  of the Saurashtra Act when the tenant sub-let the premises during the currency of that Act

issues.text: Whether s.13(1)(e) of the Bombay Act applies to sub-letting that occurred before its coming into operation

anchor.surface_text: Section 13 1  e  of the Bombay Act provides When landlord may recover Possession.- Notwithstanding anything contained in this Act but subject to the provisions of s. 15, a landlord shall be entitled to recover pos- session of any premises if the Court is satisfied-  e  that the tenant has, since the coming into operation of this Act unlawfully sub-let the whole or part of the premises or assigned or transferred in any other manner his interest therein.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lower court finding accepted; statutory language not subject to contract to contrary.

holdings.text: The Saurashtra Act nowhere insists that the landlord should issue a notice and terminate the tenancy before instituting a suit for recovery of possession under s. 13(1)(e) on the ground that the tenant had sub-let the premises.

anchor.surface_text: The Saurashtra Act nowhere insists that the landlord should issue a notice and terminate the tenancy before instituting a suit for recovery of possession under s. 13 1 e

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual interpretation of s.13(1)(e); no provision mandating prior notice.

holdings.text: Under s.111 of the Transfer of Property Act, a lease may be determined by forfeiture only if the tenant commits a breach of a condition entailing forfeiture; mere sub-letting is not such a breach unless prohibited by the contract of tenancy.

anchor.surface_text: Section III of the Transfer of Property Act provides that a lease- may be determined by forfeiture if the tenant commits breach of any of the conditions of the contract

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory interpretation of TPA s.111(g); requires contractual prohibition for sub-letting to be breach.

holdings.text: Since the contract of tenancy contained no prohibition against sub-letting, the landlord could not terminate the tenancy by notice under the Transfer of Property Act on the ground of sub-letting.

anchor.surface_text: the contract of tenancy contained no prohibition against the tenant sub-letting the premises

anchor.surface_text: It would follow that a right accrued to the landlord to recover possession under s. 13 1  of the Saurashtra Act when the tenant sub-let the premises during the currency of that Act

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accrued right preserved by saving clause; no notice prerequisite; High Court correctly upheld decree.

anchor.surface_text: Hamilton Coll v. While 1

precedents.cited_proposition: the provision of s. 38 f c of the English Interpretation Act, corresponding to s. 51, proviso 2, of the Bombay Act, was not intended to preserve abstract rights conferred by the repealed Act and that it applies only to the specific rights given to an individual upon the happening of one or more events specified in the statute
precedents.cited_holding: a tenants general right to compensation for disturbance would not survive the repeal of the Agricultural Holdings Act, 1908. But where a landlord before the repeal had given his tenant notice to quit the tenant had acquired a right which would accrue when he quitted his holding-the right to receive compensation

anchor.surface_text: Abbott Minister of Lands 2

precedents.cited_proposition: the mere right existing at the date of the repealing statute to take advantage of the provisions of the Act repealed was not a right accrued within the meaning of the saving clause
precedents.cited_holding: The Judicial Committee held that the mere right existing at the date of the repealing statute to take advantage of the provisions of the Act repealed was not a right accrued within the meaning of the saving clause

precedents.citation: Director of Public Works v. Ho Po Sang 3

anchor.surface_text: Director of Public Works v. Ho Po Sang 3

precedents.case_name: Director of Public Works v Ho Po Sang
precedents.cited_proposition: fact that the Director of Public Works had given a Crown lessee notice of his intention to grant a rebuilding certificate which would enable the lessee to recover vacant possession from the persons in occupation of the premises did not confer any right to the certificate on the lessee since various conditions had remained to be fulfilled before the certificate could be granted so that the lessee had no more than a hope that it would be granted
precedents.cited_holding: It may be therefore that under some repealed enactment a right has been given but that in respect of it some investigation or legal proceeding is necessary. The right is then unaffected and preserved. It will be preserved even if a process of quantification is necessary. But there is a manifest distinction between an investigation in respect of a right and an investigation which is to decide whether some right should or should not be given. Upon a repeal the former is preserved by the Interpretation Act The latter is not

precedents.case_name: Free Lanka Insurance Co Ltd v Ranasinghe
precedents.cited_proposition: the distinction between what was and what was not a right must often be one of great finance and a claim given by the Ceylon Motor Car Ordinance of 1936 to an injured person against the other party involved in an accident was something more than a mere hope or expectation he had in truth a right although that right might fairly be called inchoate or contingent
precedents.cited_holding: Lord Evershed said that the distinction between what was and what was not a right must often be one of great finance and the Court held that a claim given by the Ceylon Motor Car Ordinance of 1936 to an injured person against the other party involved in an accident was something more than a mere hope or expectationhe had in truth a rightal- though that right might fairly be called inchoate or contingent
